metadata.title: Securing Learning Machines:. Learn the Fundamentals Behind the Buzz… | by Ron Flores Del Rosario | Towards Data Science

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: IBM Applied Data Science with Python
DeepLearning.AI Neural Networks and Deep Learning
Fundamentals of Deep Learning for Computer Vision by NVIDIA
Make Your Own Neural Network by Tariq Rashid.
Coding the Deep Learning Revolution by Dr. Andy Thomas
Machine Learning Yearning: Technical Strategy for AI Engineers in the Era of Deep Learning by Andrew Ng
TensorFlow for Deep Learning: From Linear Regression to Reinforcement Learning by Ramsundar and Zadeh

all_paragraphs: You were just hired by a promising and well-funded “A.I. and ML” tech startup located somewhere in expensive Silicon Valley as their first Security Engineer.

You met all their requirements from a “technology stack” experience, you displayed zest and passion on how to approach complex security problems during your interviews. You agreed on the offer and you are all set to start on your first day.

You have zero knowledge nor experience in Machine Learning (ML), Artificial Neural Networks (ANN), and the new darling of the marketing world, “Artificial Intelligence” (A.I.) In this entire story we will refer to this technology stack as ML/ANN/AI for simplicity.
Imagine you have only two weeks to get up-to-speed with the technology supporting the product stack.
Where and how do you start? Books? Online courses? Just Google stuff?

First of all, don’t blame yourself. You are not a laggard. These are bleeding-edge technology creeping up into mainstream software products lately because of the explosion of readily available frameworks to use.
These frameworks include Caffe, TensorFlow, PyTorch, NVIDIA DIGITS and RAPIDS, and Cloud Computing-based offerings from Amazon AWS, Google Cloud Platform and Microsoft Azure.
Everyone calls this the “Democratization of Machine Learning”
I personally believe that given enough motivation and time, you can still catch up with the technology to be an effective security engineer even without hands-on experience in ML/ANN/AI.
Understanding the fundamentals and building blocks of ML/ANN/AI is your priority.
The rest, which is the actual implementation in code and infrastructure of the product you are supporting, you can learn as you go.
It’s an uphill battle for a security engineer to secure a new product or service based on bleeding-edge technology without understanding the fundamentals or core principles behind them.
Here are some of my personal recommendations on how you can grasp the fundamentals in a short amount of time so you can start helping in securing the product:

“Understanding the fundamentals and building blocks of ML/ANN/AI is your priority. The rest, which is the actual implementation in code and infrastructure of the product you are supporting, you can learn them as you go.”

(Note: This is a personal recommendation and the path I took to get acquainted with ML/ANN/AI technology stack. It is by no means the only way, feel free to pick the only ones you like. I have no business relationship with the creators of the courses and book authors)

My suggested pre-requisite before starting the path is to brush-up on your Python scripting/coding knowledge. I no longer write code on a daily basis before I started my learning path so I struggled a bit with Python. But If I can do it, so can you.
Here’s the learning path I took:
1. IBM Data Science Foundations — Level 1 (Free)
Introduction to Data Science Concepts, Methodology, Toolkit, and Business Use Cases. Time to complete: 3 Hours
2. IBM Data Science Foundations — Level 2 (Free)
Continuation of the Level 1 Course. Review of the introductory concepts, deeper discussion, and practice on Data Science Tools and Data Science Methodology. Time to complete: 13 Hours
3. IBM Applied Data Science with Python (Free)

Now it’s time to apply the Data Science concepts and methodologies you learned on the previous Data Science Foundations course. This course will teach you how to use Python language to clean, analyze and visualize data. The lecture labs are short but helpful so you get hands-on experience in tackling interesting data problems. Dives into Data Analysis and Data Visualization using Python. Learn how to use the basics of de-facto Python libraries for Data Science pandas, Matplotlib, Seaborn, and Folium. Time to complete: 23 Hours.
4. IBM Machine Learning with Python (Free)

This course will introduce you to the basics of Machine Learning using Python. It will introduce you to Supervised and Unsupervised Machine Learning, popular algorithms like Classification, Regression, Clustering, and Dimensional Reduction, and popular models Train/Test Split, Root Mean Squared Error and Random Forests. Time to complete: 12 Hours.
5. DeepLearning.AI Neural Networks and Deep Learning ($$$)
Created and taught by Andrew Ng, a globally recognized Machine Learning pioneer. Dives deep into the theories and math behind the evolution of Neural Networks and Deep Learning.
Prepare for Heavy Math and brush-up on your Linear Algebra. This course will dive deep into Deep Learning introduction, Neural Network Basics, and Shallow and Deep Neural Networks.

The whiteboard sessions may put you to sleep due to heavy notations and equations, make sure you take some timely breaks so you absorb the key concepts. Practice writing the notations on your own cheatsheet or whiteboard to reinforce learning and visual recognition.

The programming exercises on this course are totally worth the grind. You will be working on a Jupyter Notebook which you should already know by now after going over the previous foundational courses. Time to complete: 18 Hours.
“Practice writing the notations on your own cheatsheet or whiteboard to reinforce learning and visual recognition.”
6. Fundamentals of Deep Learning for Computer Vision by NVIDIA ($$$)

This is an excellent introductory course with hands-on configuration and coding exercises on NVIDIA’s DIGITS platform for image classification and object detection. Get acquainted with award-winning pre-trained models in image classification AlexNet, GoogleLeNet, LeNet and UNET already available for use on the platform.

You will explore the fundamentals of Deep Learning and learn how to train and improve the performance of a neural network, learn Deep Learning workflows, experiment with data, training parameters (aka Hyperparameter tuning), network structure, and other tweaks to increase performance and capability of your neural network.
Completing this course immediately gave me a lot of ideas and business use-case for image classification using the platform. Time to complete: 8+ hours.
Arranged in order, below are my recommended books for you to read to either improve on your foundational knowledge or expand on them.
I am not yet 100% done with all these books, but it’s very helpful to shuffle reading from one book to another for a change of pace and to help you in your learning path.
1. Make Your Own Neural Network by Tariq Rashid.
Probably the best introductory material I’ve read about Neural Networks. Explained like how the great Richard Feynman would explain it (Explain it like I’m Five/ELI5)
2. Pragmatic AI by Noah Gift

Written by a good friend and fellow Jiu-Jitsu practitioner, Noah has been in the Data Science space for years. Get up-to-speed in modern developer workflows and how to leverage Cloud Computing services for running Machine Learning workloads. Very useful in the workplace.
3. Coding the Deep Learning Revolution by Dr. Andy Thomas

An ideal companion book for engineers. Introduces Deep Learning concepts and models. Learn how to use Python, Tensorflow, and Keras. Lots of sample code and coding exercises to work on. Very useful in the workplace.
4. Machine Learning Yearning: Technical Strategy for AI Engineers in the Era of Deep Learning by Andrew Ng

Sign-up and get a DRAFT copy of the book by Andrew Ng, a globally-recognized leader in the field. Eloquent write-up and easy to read. Not so heavy on the technical or math side. Advocates workflow simplicity and you get tips and guidance from Andrew himself!
5. TensorFlow for Deep Learning: From Linear Regression to Reinforcement Learning by Ramsundar and Zadeh

Learn the fundamentals of machine learning through TensorFlow, Google’s famous software library for deep learning that makes it straightforward for engineers to design and deploy sophisticated deep learning architectures. Learn how to use TensorFlow to build systems capable of detecting objects in images, understanding human text, and predicting the properties of potential medicines.
To sum it up, I’d like to reiterate the goal of this learning path:

As an incoming Security Engineer for a startup, you need to understand the fundamental principles, theories, techniques, and modern tooling involved in the creation of a software product using ML/ANN/AI so you have the minimum knowledge and context to secure the product.
Having the proper context is a must to be able to generate a minimum viable Threat Model of the product you are tasked to secure.
(Mastery is a different thing and often requires at a minimum of 10,000 hours of deliberate practice on your craft or domain of expertise.)

If you add the total estimated hours to finish the online courses, it amounts to 80+ hours, which is around three days. Realistically speaking I would say a week to go through the courses, which includes research on the coding exercises through Stack Overflow and GitHub mostly. I was able to accomplish these courses by studying at home from 9 AM to 12 MN for two weeks straight.

Currently, I am enjoying shuffling through the list of books I provided, and exploring cool GitHub projects such as Uber’s Ludwig Project and NVIDIA’s DIGITS platform, and how it can help us Security Engineers rapidly prototype tools for Information Security augmented by ML/ANN/AI.
If you are just starting your learning path, undecided, stuck, please let me know, and will do my best to respond and help.

Enjoy your learning path. There will be obstacles and hard to digest concepts, especially if you are coming from a non-computer science educational background, but as the saying goes, “It’s not the destination, its the journey”
Now go and find your Y. Get it?
